title: Description of the Natural Beauty of the Falls (1852, unknown author)
subject: text; unspoiled landscape
description: Part 1 from an account about the natural beauty of Niagara Falls. It describes it as the "Titan of America" and praises its mighty forests, cascading waves of the river and majestic animals.

title: Continued: Description of the Natural Beauty of the Falls (1852, unknown author)
subject: text; unspoiled landscape
description: Part 2 from the account of the natural beauty of Niagara Falls. In addition to the admiration of the landscape, the author disapproves the developments that surround the landscape: "Civilization on every side, weighs, as it were, like lead upon its wings."

title: Aerial View of Both Falls, Facing Victoria Park
subject: photogravure; development; tourism; clifton hill
description: This is a photogravure from a tourist guide called "Photo-gravures of Niagara Falls" by Adolph Wittemann, made in 1898. The book contains travel guides and detailed tips to aid tourists of the area. The aerial perspective of this photo, taken from the The Clifton Hotel, demonstrates the juxtaposition of the modern Victoria Park across from the Falls. The caption describes the "amusements" available at the hotel.

title: "Niagara Falls Already Ruined!" by Alton D. Adams
subject: water rights; diversion; magazine; article; industrialization; hydroelectricity; unspoiled landscape
description: This is a magazine article hotly criticizing the hydroelectric companies and development at Niagara Falls, written Alton D. Adams in The Technical World Magazine, April 1906. He expresses anxiety over the American Falls running dry while the Canadian Falls remains unaffected. "If the capitalists and promoters who now hold franchises were to all establish plants, the entire flow of Niagara river would be diverted into underground channels; and the mighty cliff over which the torrent now pours in resistless grandeur would be left rugged and bald and dry."

title: The Excavation of the Canadian Channel for a Forebay
subject: hydroelectricity; excavation; diversion; industrialization
description: A photograph from the Adams article depicting the excavation and construction of a forebay in the Canadian Channel. A forebay is an artifical reservoir which holds water and diverts it to the power stations.

title: Map of Power Developments at Niagara Falls
subject: hydroelectricity; plants; map; development; business
description: A historical map detailing the boundaries, hydrological features, streets and power stations of Niagara Falls. Solid black shapes represent the numerous power stations built on various sites around the Falls.

title: Map of the Niagara Power District
subject: hydroelectricity; plants; map; development; business
description: A historical map highlighting the power stations, transmission lines and railroad lines of the power district, in the Niagara Region and beyond. The properties of the various companies, including the Ontario Power Company, have been coloured according to the companies that owne them, which are listed in the legend in the bottom right corner.

title: A View of the Bank of American Mills
subject: hydroelectricity; plants; water diversion;`
description: A photograph from an article titled "The Electrical Features of Niagara", from The Electrical World Magazine, June 5, 1897, vol. 29, no. 23. It shows the power stations of Niagara Falls Hydraulic Power and Manufacturing Company along the high bank, releasing water from the hydroelectricity back into the Niagara river.

title: Caricature of the Power Companies
subject: caricature; power company; water rights; hydroelectricity; diversion
description: A cartoon of a "commerical exploiter" whose "clutching hands of greed and cunning" have diverted the water from the falls for hydroelectic power. It was featured in an article called "Who Owns the Earth and How Did They Get It? The New Monopoly in Water" in The Technical World Magazine, February 1909, vol. 10 no. 6, which discusses and objects to the use of the Falls for hydroelectric power. ..."Unless the public does wake up and awakes in wrath, twenty-five years will add to the present peerage of Ironmasters, Coal Kings, Land Barons and Petroleum Princes a vastly greater list of Monarchs of Water” (Hyde 554-5).

title: A Crowd at Prospect Point
subject: tourism; prospect point
description: A stereo card showing a crowd of interested tourists gathered to look out at the Falls, carrying umbrellas to protect from the mist. The inscription reads "Admiring Tourits viewing the Falls, from Prospect Point, Niagara, USA."

title: A View of the Falls From Under a Suspension Bridge
subject: tourism; bridge; river; industrialization
description: A stereo card showing two viewers admiring the Falls from atop one of the suspension bridges over the Niagara River. The reverse of the card reads "The Majesty and Beauty of Niagara. No. 7844, '5. General View of the Falls, Looking under Suspension Bridge."

title: Upper Steel Arch Bridge
subject: bridge; river; streetcar; industrialization; photogravure
description: A photogravure from the tourist guide "Photo-gravures of Niagara Falls" by Adolph Wittemann (1898). It depicts the Upper Steel Arch Bridge as a streetcar passes over it. It connects New York with Ontario over the river, at a length of about 1240 feet.

title: Goat Island Bridge
subject: bridge; river; goat island; tourism
description: A photogravure from the tourist guide "Photo-gravures of Niagara Falls" by Adolph Wittemann (1898), depicting a bridge to Goat Island that crosses the American rapids.

title: Cave of the Winds Newsprint
subject: tourism; cave; rainbow; advertising
description: A promotional print detailing the bridges, dressing rooms and tunnels available for tourists when they take the guided tour of the Cave of the Winds on Goat Island. The Cave is touted as being the only place on Earth where rainbows form a complete circle.

title: "The Passing of Niagara", by Mary B. Hartt
subject: hydroelectricity; unspoiled landscape; critique; article
description: An excellent example of the nineteenth century ideal of "unspoiled landscape". This is an article called "The Passing of Niagara" by Mary B. Hartt from 1901, and it describes the downfall of Niagara's natural beauty since its discovery in 1678 by Father Louis Hennepin. She laments the loss of lush forests and untouched cliffs, calling the developments "blemishes" and "mutilations"."Gone are the mighty cedars, and gone with them the strong-winged eagles. In place of the cedar has sprung up the telegraph-pole. In place of the screaming eagle has come the shrieking trolley-wire. In place of the solitary Red Man have come scurrying hordes of pale-faced picnickers. The sardine has entered Paradise."

title: The Pre-Industrial Bridal Veil
subject: hydroelectricity; mills; water rights; bridal veil; unspoiled landscape
description: An image from Mary B. Hartt's "The Passing of Niagara" (1901), which shows what the high bank used to look like before the mills and power stations of the power companies were constructed there (an act which the caption calls disfigurement). The bank used to be called "The Bridal Veil".
